A little late to the question. Seems unlikely that anything radical would happen in one week. However, the Israeli water co has shut off West Bank water for the past week : http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2016/06/israel-water-cuts-west-bank-full-crisis-mode-160620133005799.html

If the date were, say, Oct 1 2016, then there might be some justification for one party to announce a halt. Where is the political leverage to a change in status before July 1?

Preserving Israeli-Palestinian Security Cooperation
In addition to giving the PA a badly needed measure of credibility among the populace, establishing police stations in such areas can help it counter the widespread criticism that security cooperation with Israel is tantamount to collaboration. As the mayor of al-Ram pointed out on Wednesday, PA leaders can now claim that their policies are producing small but tangible steps toward Palestinian independence.
This development could not have been imaginable without ongoing Israeli-Palestinian security cooperation. Under former prime minister Salam Fayyad, the PA security forces were restructured with indispensable support from the United States Security Coordinator (USSC) and Jordan. Since then, security cooperation with Israel has reached unprecedented depth, breadth, consistency, and professionalism.
[from the Washington Institute]

Downgrading the chances of this now that Lieberman has begun his post. Haven't heard any movement on this issue. Don't think Bibi will do something this drastic now that his coalition appears a little more robust.

Ok, so the Oslo accords were signed in '93 and '95, call it '94 to give it a singular point. That means that in 22 years, there's been one suspension of the security co-operation, which gives us a base line of 4.5% chance per year.

Iran, no friend of either the PA or Israel, is attempting to increase terrorist activity. Bad news for continued cooperation. Time to monitor this question closely.

Down from 25% last month, to be nearer consensus (currently 5%).  A sudden flare up in the next four months could easily go out of control and result in a halt in cooperation, but the status quo seems most likely to persist.
Headed down 10% for scoring purposes. I still think the bar for this question might be very low, but I've been above consensus.

The US Government will try for one last push to get the governments of Israel and PA to come to an agreement before they are voted out in November (regardless of who wins, there is almost no chance that John Kerry will be asked to stay on board).  This push will enflame the tension between Hamas and Fatah, causing one of them to need to show "independence" by striking out at Israel.  Israel will want to counter and keep the peace, and will do so by cracking down hard on the resistance (Not sure which one of these actions will formally halt the agreement, but after both, I think it will be safe to assume that it is halted).

Updating for the passage of time
No advantage, either rational or emotional, to either side to do this just now.

This coming summer is a likely candidate for the "every 2-3 year" war in Gaza. This would be Hamas in Gaza taking more ownership of the current escalation in Israeli-Palestinian violence. The Palestinian Authority ceasing cooperation would in fact be a license for Hamas to strengthen its hold in the West Bank, creating more cause for a mass Israeli incursion into West Bank villages and cities. This makes the PA look weak and nullifies to an extent the relevance of the PA whose biggest strength is its security apparatus. Israel has no incentive to cease cooperation as it is one of the most effective ways of curbing violence coming from the West Bank. The "lone wolf" attacks of recent "offer" an even larger competitive advantage to the PA apparatus as it is closer to the ground.
Both need some sense of stability for economic reasons.

If it didn't happen during the last conflagration then I don't see any reason for it to happen with the recent uptick in attacks. Predicting something more severe than what happened in the summer of 2014 is difficult as you never know what will spark it. Given, as the "more info" section tells us, that it has only been suspended once since this Oslo Accords we have an extremely low base rate of around 5% per year. Since there are only 6 months left until the question expires we could perhaps cut this number in half.
It would be interesting to see what would happen if Israel did suspend the cooperation, but the violence has not risen to a tipping point just yet for Israel.

---
It's not just that PA President Mahmoud Abbas is 80 years old and there is no clear successor in line to replace him. Palestinians are distrustful of Abbas personally, but more than that, they are fed up with the entire PA system. Some 20 years after the PA was established as a temporary measure meant to bring Palestinians closer to peace and a state, the conflict persists. Palestinians increasingly see the PA as a tool of the Israeli occupation, which many doubt will ever end.
The real politique would suggest that despite all the current problems they have with each other, they stillneed to cooperate on security

As Palestine pursues its other options, i.e., not through negotiating with Israel, which only wastes time while Israel settles more of Palestine, the desire of Israel to cooperate with Palestine decreases, and from the other side, the need for Palestine to cooperate with Israel decreases as well.  Palestine is taking the game to a different arena, where they are likely to get more sympathy.

What's the point? There are lots of ways to cease cooperating without the declaration, and both parties are extremely familiar with the menu of options. Even the short media burst of attention such an announcement would provoke wouldn't mean anything at this point.
There is no point to such an announcement.  It just makes the party look bad.
(no change) Time horizon is ~6 months. No "minimum" suspension required for a yes. Think therefore it might be likelier than the consensus (long term break is harder to imagine).
Dropping based on time and little to press coverage to support.

While anything can certainly happen in this volitile region, this analysis posted yesterday suggests the PA does not have a strong incentive to stop cooperating even in the face of public opinion to do so. It seems relatively objective.
President Abbas relies on Israel security service for his physical survival.
The PLA, Israel and Hamas/Hezbollah are all focused on the more pressing issue of IS. Until this threat is neutralized sufficiently I believe these groups will limit conflict to deal with IS first.
Perhaps only a temporary one, but yes.
A good reason to maintain security cooperation:
Despite anger and blood, both sides will refrain from such an obvious escalation. No specific benefit would come from ending 'security cooperation' even though it has been a defacto failure for years

Both sides have too much to lose by pulling out of a security cooperation. Unless there is an all out war between the two sides (probably a 2% chance) the security cooperation should stay in place even if there are other incidents that occur.
Israel has a hard-line government who ride roughshod over the Palestinians

PA Security Cooperative sources an enormous number of jobs for the Palestinians. Leaked papers over the last few years have shown that despite and during great tumult, far greater cooperation proceeds beneath the extreme public tension. What's the old saying about keeping your friends close and your enemies closer?
Will likely keep muddlying (but not through...). No reason for not trying to co-operate foreseen.
Affirming forecast of 11 November.  I'm not aware of any relevant recent news that could impact this question.
(no change) Last year there was at least one question related to Jordan and ISIS. Wonder what if any impact the whole DAESH/ISIS mess might have on the PA?
It going to get worse before ...
The alternatives for both are worse.
The PA will be reluctant to halt security cooperation entirely.

There is a concern of a 3rd intifada. There is currently bloodshed amongst civilians. There is unrest. However, the more pressing issue of ISIS may just postpone the halt to their cooperation until maybe 2017. If ISIS is dealt with quicker than that, then it will be more likely for the above question to be mostly YES.
There remain common threats.  The need for peace is still strong enough to keep the parties looking for a long term ways to survive together.
The PA would effectively cease to exist in that case. Neither side wishes this to happen.
Both sides need to at least keep up a facade of peaceful intent. It would not be in their interest to act otherwise, and halting security cooperation would send the wrong message.

No change, but wording of the question and Sjens comment triggered a thought. It would be easy for either party to unofficially withdraw or suspend some level of cooperation without announcing it. Suspect this would be more likely than a formal break. If so, then news might leak out and would complicate resolving this question.

I don't believe Israel will announce a halt in "security cooperation", since it would further loose control over the situation. For the Palestinians: This issue has already been discussed for months with no results. On 19. Nov the Secretary-Generalâ€™s Special Coordinator for the Middle East Peace Process told the Security Council: "Security coordination between Israel and the Palestinian Authority must be bolstered and Israeli security forces should only use firearms to address imminent threats of death or serious injury." I think both sides will take care not to openly back out of the UN efforts in this case, though neither side is happy the arrangement.

Nothing seems to be going on here beyond the customary quacking and flapping on both sides.

Seems like this has been constantly discussed by the media over the last several years.  Likely just political posturing by both sides due to grave consequences that would affect both sides.  Unlikely, but possible.
I think there's a slight chance that a problem will metastasize into a halt in security cooperation, specifically because Israel will take advantage of the US Presidential Election.

Raising my forecast somewhat on the argument that it is a long time until June.
And ALOT seems to be happening in the world...
Without cooperation, neither side can accuse the other of not cooperating!  Each side needs the other to excoriate in the press while doing the real politics behind the scenes.
It is necessary to keep the security agreement because without the Oslo Accords they have nothing to keep them with the possibility of 2 state solution.
Hard to see how this is in anybody's interest. There are other, less drastic, outlets for a temper tantrum on either side.
There's always hope, as the Israeli national anthem says.
Neither party wants to be the one to officially suspend cooperation. Unofficial foot dragging is a separate issue, as are threats to suspend.

Getting close to the point of no return....continued decline of status quo will lead to this

The Palestinians will suspend.  
They have not been happy with the results so far and they want to send a message to Israel.

The Palestinian authority has had its credibility to cooperate with Israel eroded so bad that its leadership has been left with fewer options. The only thing that it can do to bolster its fledgling fortunes is to do something radical like suspending cooperation with Israel. With the violence spiraling out of control. It is likely that this will happen soon in the coming year.
The bombings and killings in France will draw the Palestinians closer to Israel as they each see the idiocy and futility of their war.
The arrangement serves Israel's purpose and the PA is too weak to stand on its own.
My guess is the political cost to either side is too high for them to stop.
The cost may be high for both sides.
Neither side wants to be first and therefore blamed

Israel needs to be perceived as being willing to negotiate and agree to a peace treaty, especially under Obama.
While the PA is concerned of ISIS and their growing strength and radicalization. The PA needs more stability and time to rebuild their land after their disastrous missile attacks on Israel. Stability for both groups is desired today.
Israelis are benefit g from security cooperation and thus they will not stop it. As for the palestinians, the cost will be very high if they stop.

It seems the Palestinians are fed up with the Oslo Accords, as seen in the poll cited in the article linked below. However that doesn't mean that the current PA leadership is rushing to halt the cooperation, particularly as they could face international donor fund reductions. I have several unknowns though, like how will violence pan out in Israel by the closing of the question, will Abbas still be heading te PA by then, what are Israelâ€™s motivations to halt an agreement? I'm leaning toward no, but not by a lot (45 yes). I do not know a lot about the topic and would adjust my probability by using some crowd averaging giving it a bit more weight to account for my gaps. Initial estimate 30.
As long as Abu Mazen remains in control of P.A.  security cooperation likely to continue. Recent violence could flare, however, putting a lot of pressure on both sides.
Escalation of discord increasing in degree as well as frequency
Though there is tension between them, they work together against a common enemy, Hamas.

Joint police cooperation is a cornerstone of the "two state solution". Abandonment of security cooperation is a de facto admission that the PA has abandoned the two state solution. Not likely if Abu Mazen remains leader of the PA because he will always remain faithful to the two state solution to secure the support of the EU & US. My opinion is that Israel has effectively abandoned a two state solution, even though Bibi claims he is always ready to talk.
Depends on the Temple Mount unrest.

Neither side will announce a halt, since that would be bad PR. But I would think that neither side would refrain from provoking the other to make such an announcement. Result: no cooperation, but the formal agreement remains in place.
Probably not. Israel has no partner to talk about in deed, but that's is the reality since ever. Abbas needs the cooperation to stay in power.

Not likely. given Netanyahu's recent courting of American politicians. My guess is given his political capital he expended on trying to halt the Iran deal, that he would be unlikely to make Israel a more primary focus of the American election. That would be a highly uncertain gamble. He has far more to gain by trying to maintain peace and stability.

It's not in the interest of either side to halt security cooperation. However, one can't discount the possibility, given the long history of mistrust, street violence and disproportionate Israeli reactions.

Both sides have too much to lose from a more formal or conclusive breakdown in security co-operation, however much that both current leaderships have a taste for ignorant, ill-informed, inciteful, and belligerent rhetoric.
If Barack is still paying for Bibi's cluster bombs after last year's lawn mowing episode, I guess it's business as usual over there, so I'll come down a lot.

The beef seems to be not with the PA or Fatah militias but with the Internet and underemployed youth

Both sides presently have only unilateral desire for a solution.  This will take a Deus Ex Machina event to end the conflict.

Two aspects seem important. Political and security. The first might (events aren't encouraging) lean toward a halt; the second would probably heavily favor continuing on the theory that one can make a bad situation worse and that the consequences might likely be "high consequence." Any significant leadership change would definitely be a wild card.

There would be a nontrivial public relations cost to whichever party pulls the plug, no matter how badly things seem to be going.  Both gangs would probably prefer to leave the paper in place for the nonce.  On the other hand, it is never wise to bet strongly against stupidity anywhere, and especially not between these two.
